reviewText: LEGENDS OF COMEDY from Reader's Digest is a 3 VHS tape series available in a sturdy gloss-coated storage case or as individual programs. Each runs a little under an hour, has HiFi audio and is of fine quality. Narration provides only general information about what's on screen. Volume #1, Golden Age of Comedy - 1920s - 1930s consists primarily of silent era film clips. A few of these are badly worn and have multiple scratch lines. All are projected at 24 fps, which causes the action on screen to be exaggeratedly fast (18 fps was a standard speed for silents, with some run even slower). There's a few rarities here, however most selections are taken from widely available shorts. PROGRAM (all clips are rather brief)-- 1.) Turn-of-the-century excerpts include urban traffic, handcranked nickelodeons, behind the scenes on Hollywood production, Lillian Russell, Houdini and others. 2.) JOHN BUNNY (cinema's first comedy star). 3.) MACK SENNETT: Cyclorama, Keystone Kops, Fatty Arbuckle, Mabel Normand, Sennett Bathing Beauties, Gloria Swanson, Carole Lombard. 4.) MABEL NORMAND: "The Extra Girl" (1923), "Mabel's Stratagem" (1912). 5.) BUSTER KEATON: "One Week" (1920), "Steamboat Bill Jr." (1928), et.al. 6.) CHARLIE CHAPLIN: "The Rink" (1916), "The Cure" (1917), "Gentlemen of Nerve (1914), and others. 7.) 'SNUB' POLLARD: "It's a Gift" (1923). 8.) Footage of Armistice Day celebrations. 9.) HARRY LANGDON: "Soldier Man" (1926), "His Marriage Wows" (1925). 10.) HAROLD LLOYD: As Willie Work and Lonesome Luke, plus "Safety Last!" (1923), "The Freshman" (1925), "The Sin of Harold Diddlebock" (1947). 11.) WILL ROGERS: Radio clips, plus Rogers parodying actors and films. 12.) HAL ROACH: Silent Our Gang footage, plus the "Our Gang Follies of 1938" (1937) has Alfala singing "Barber of Seville" and "Learn to Croon." CHARLEY CHASE: With circus lion and trying to fence with a dagger. LAUREL & HARDY: Early Hardy short, plus "The Stolen Jools" (1931), "Lucky Dog" (1921), "The Flying Deuces" (1939), and misc. 13.) W.C. FIELDS: "Pool Sharks" (1915), "The Pharmacist" (1933), "The Dentist" (1932), "The Barber Shop" (1933), "The Fatal Glass of Beer" (1933). LEGENDS OF COMEDY, Vol. 2 is subtitled Great Stars of Film and Radio - The Fabulous 40's.
